conversations.content: The Dragon's Fortune: Part One
The great dragon of the land of Hinomoto, Amaterasu, ordered Shishimai to spread good fortune. But what WAS good fortune? He was not altogether sure.
＂Perhaps it's something people are happy to receive,＂ he thought. And so, Shishimai decided to rid the farmers of their arduous work.
Shishimai descended to the human village, danced a strange dance, and told the people he was there to bless them. When he finished, the fields overflowed with bounty.
The villagers were overjoyed, and heaped thanks and praise on the dragon. But they soon became fat because of Shishimai's largess, and quickly ceased to think of him at all.
Thinking this behavior strange, Shishimai reported it to Lady Amaterasu—who was furious.
＂Your actions have made the people lazy!＂ she cried. ＂Now they take the bounty of the fields for granted. This is the opposite of good fortune!＂
Shishimai pondered his next move, and eventually decided to work the fields himself, spending uncountable days sweating alongside the people.
The villagers were overjoyed at his assistance. But soon they came to depend on it, then to abuse it. Finally, they abandoned the fields and waited for him to do it all.
Thinking this behavior strange, Shishimai reported it to Lady Amaterasu—who was again furious.
＂It is good that you help,＂ she said. ＂But they will not recognize this as a dragon's blessing if you blend in with them. This will bring the opposite of good fortune!＂
Shishimai knew he could not afford to fail a third time, and so he wracked his brain for a perfect solution to the problem.
One day, he had a flash of brilliance. Chuckling to himself, he instantly began to set his plan in motion...
The Dragon's Fortune: Part Two
Shishimai was working and failing at bringing good fortune to the people, but he was confident in his new idea.
An elated Shishimai rushed to the village and began to dance. It was a dance of appreciation, one meant to encourage the working farmers.
The villagers were overjoyed, and though their work was hard, Shishimai's dance motivated them to push through the pain.
Soon, they began to work hard in anticipation of the dance, which only emboldened Shishimai. As a result, the fields flourished and the village thrived.
Overjoyed, Shishimai returned to Lady Amaterasu and told her what he had done. She listened carefully, then responded with a question:
＂This is good. But do you understand why you failed the first two times?＂ When Shishimai replied that he did not, Lady Amaterasu continued.
＂Humans are not thankful for the rain while sitting near a gurgling spring. Fortune indeed makes them happy,  but once they take it for granted, it is no longer a blessing.＂
Shishimai nodded at her words. ＂I see,＂ he said. ＂Though it makes me sad, I'll only dance once a year.＂
As much as he enjoyed dancing, he could not fail a third time. And so he committed to saving his efforts for but one day a year.
That is why, even today, one can see Shishimai's dance in Hinomotoan villages only on New Year's Day.
...But what does Shishimai do on the other days of the year?
Why, he sleeps, of course! What good fortune he has!
